The rain hammered against the cracked windows of the abandoned warehouse, each droplet striking like bullets against the glass. Roger Grimwald pressed his massive frame against the cold brick wall, his yellowed eyes scanning the empty street below. At seven feet tall with arms thick as tree trunks, he was a mountain of malice wrapped in tattered clothing that barely contained his bulk. His uncle's funeral had been three months ago, but the rage still burned fresh in his chest like molten metal.

"Should've been me who inherited everything," he growled to himself, his voice a gravelly whisper that seemed to echo off the walls. "That old fool promised me the estate, the money, all of it." His thick fingers curled into fists, knuckles cracking audibly in the silence. Uncle Mortimer had changed his will at the last minute, leaving everything to some distant cousin Roger had never even met. The betrayal cut deeper than any blade.

The sound of heels clicking against wet pavement drew his attention back to the street. A young woman in a red coat hurried along the sidewalk, clutching her purse tightly against her chest. Her auburn hair caught the dim glow of the streetlights, and Roger felt something dark and twisted unfurl in his stomach. The anger, the grief, the overwhelming sense of injustice—it all crystallized into something far more sinister.

He'd been watching women for weeks now, following them through the city's winding streets and narrow alleyways. At first, it had been mindless wandering, a way to channel his fury into something concrete. But gradually, it had become something else entirely. Something that made him laugh in the darkness of his makeshift lair, a sound that would have chilled anyone who heard it.

The woman in the red coat turned down a side street, and Roger's lips pulled back in what might have been a smile if it hadn't been so devoid of warmth. He pushed away from the wall, his heavy footsteps silent despite his size. Years of hunting in the woods with Uncle Mortimer had taught him how to move without sound, how to track prey without being detected. Those skills served a different purpose now.

Twenty-three hundred miles away in Anchorage, Lady Unedo Martinez was reviewing crime scene photographs by the pale light of her desk lamp. The police station was nearly empty at this hour, just the night shift officers and a few detectives burning the midnight oil on active cases. Unedo had earned her reputation as one of Alaska's most tenacious investigators through cases exactly like this one—the kind that kept her awake at night and haunted her dreams.

The photos spread across her desk told a disturbing story. Three women in three different cities, all found in similar circumstances. No physical violence, no signs of struggle, but each victim reported being stalked for weeks before they disappeared entirely from their routines, only to resurface days later with no memory of where they'd been. The psychological trauma was severe and lasting.

"Working late again, Martinez?" Detective Jim Kowalski dropped into the chair across from her desk, a steaming cup of coffee in his hands. Jim was a good cop, methodical and thorough, but he lacked the intuitive leap that made Unedo exceptional at her job. "You know, normal people go home after their shift ends."

"Normal people don't have a serial stalker operating across state lines," Unedo replied without looking up from the photographs. Her dark hair fell across her face as she leaned forward, studying the details that everyone else seemed to miss. "Look at this pattern, Jim. Seattle, Portland, now reports coming in from San Francisco. He's moving south along the coast, and the frequency is increasing."

Jim sipped his coffee and peered at the photos with skeptical eyes. "Could be coincidence. Lot of weirdos out there, and women get stalked every day unfortunately. What makes you think it's the same guy?"

Unedo pulled out a manila folder thick with reports and witness statements. "The methodology is identical. Large male figure, described as unusually tall and broad. Always approaches from behind or from concealed positions. Never makes direct contact, just follows and watches until the victim becomes aware of his presence. Then he disappears for a few days before escalating the behavior."

"Escalating how?" Jim's expression grew more serious as he began to see the pattern Unedo had identified.

"Breaking into homes, leaving small items moved or displaced. Personal belongings going missing and then returning in different locations. Phone calls with no one speaking, just breathing on the other end." Unedo's voice grew tight with controlled anger. "This isn't random harassment, Jim. This is psychological warfare designed to break down his victims' sense of safety and reality."

The thing that truly disturbed Unedo was the complete absence of sexual assault or physical violence in any of the cases. This wasn't about gratification in the traditional sense that motivated most stalkers. This was about power, control, and the perverse pleasure of watching someone slowly come apart under the weight of constant fear and uncertainty.

Her phone rang, cutting through the quiet of the station. The caller ID showed an area code she didn't recognize, but something about the late hour made her answer immediately.

"Detective Martinez, this is Sarah Chen with San Francisco PD. I understand you've been tracking a pattern of stalking cases along the west coast?" The voice on the other end was crisp and professional, but Unedo could hear the underlying tension.

"That's correct. What's your situation down there?"

"We just had our fourth reported case in two weeks. Same MO as what you described in your advisory. Large male subject, sophisticated surveillance techniques, psychological intimidation tactics. But Detective Martinez, I think this guy might be escalating beyond stalking."

Unedo felt her stomach drop. "What do you mean?"

"Jennifer Walsh, twenty-six, marketing executive. She'd been reporting strange incidents for about ten days—feeling watched, items moved in her apartment, the usual pattern. Last night she didn't come home from work. We found her car abandoned in Golden Gate Park, keys still in the ignition, purse untouched."

"Any witnesses? Security footage?"

"That's the strange part. We have footage of her leaving her office building, getting in her car, driving toward the park. Then nothing. It's like she just vanished into thin air." Sarah's voice carried the frustration of a detective facing an impossible puzzle. "But there's something else, something that doesn't fit the pattern."

"What is it?"

"We found something at the scene. A note, handwritten, left on the driver's seat." Sarah paused, and Unedo could hear papers rustling. "It says, 'Uncle Mortimer sends his regards. The game is just beginning.'"

The line went quiet except for the static of the long-distance connection. Unedo stared at the wall above her desk, mind racing through the implications. A note meant direct communication, a departure from the anonymous stalking behavior. But more importantly, it suggested a personal motivation, some specific grievance or trauma driving the escalation.

"Detective Chen, I need you to run that name through every database you have access to. Mortimer, any spelling variation. Focus on recent deaths, estate transfers, family disputes. This might be our first real lead."

"Already on it. But Detective Martinez, there's something else you should know. We think we might have him."

Unedo sat up straighter, adrenaline flooding her system. "You made an arrest?"

"Two hours ago. Patrol officers spotted a male subject matching the description in the park area where we found the abandoned vehicle. Six-foot-eight, approximately two hundred eighty pounds, acting suspiciously. When they approached for questioning, he ran."

"Did he resist arrest?"

"Fought like a wild animal. Took six officers to bring him down, and he kept laughing the entire time. Maniacal laughter, like something out of a horror movie. Even after we got him cuffed and into the back of the patrol car, he wouldn't stop laughing."

Unedo frowned. Something about this felt wrong, too convenient after months of a perpetrator who had demonstrated sophisticated evasion skills. "What's his story? Did he say anything coherent?"

"That's just it—he hasn't said a word since we booked him. Just sits in the interview room staring at the wall and occasionally breaking into that same disturbing laughter. We're hoping you might fly down and take a look at him. Your experience with the other cases might help us break through."

"I'll catch the first flight out of Anchorage in the morning," Unedo said without hesitation. "In the meantime, keep him isolated and don't let anyone interview him until I arrive. If this is really our guy, he's been planning this for months. He won't break easily."

After ending the call, Unedo leaned back in her chair and stared at the ceiling tiles. Something nagged at her about the arrest, but she couldn't put her finger on what exactly felt off. Maybe it was the sudden shift from careful stalking to leaving evidence behind. Or perhaps it was the theatrical nature of the note, which seemed designed to provide exactly the kind of personal clue that had been absent from all the previous incidents.

Jim had been listening to her side of the conversation, and now he was studying her face with the expression of someone who knew her well enough to read her moods. "You don't think they got him, do you?"

"I think it's too early to celebrate," Unedo replied carefully. "But if there's even a chance they have the right person, I need to be there to question him. The victims deserve answers, and their families deserve justice."

She began gathering the case files and photographs into a travel folder, her mind already shifting into the focused intensity that had made her reputation. Tomorrow she would sit across from a potential serial predator and try to see into the darkness that motivated his actions. But tonight, she would prepare for every possible scenario and trust her instincts to guide her toward the truth.

The rain continued to fall outside the police station windows, and somewhere in the darkness, Roger Grimwald pressed himself deeper into the shadows and laughed softly at how perfectly his plan was unfolding.**Chapter 1: The Hunter's Game**

The fluorescent lights of the San Francisco Police Department's interrogation room cast harsh shadows across the scarred metal table, creating an atmosphere of institutional bleakness that had worn down countless suspects over the years. Detective Unedo Martinez sat across from the man they'd arrested in Golden Gate Park, studying his face with the methodical precision that had made her one of Alaska's most respected investigators. The suspect was exactly as described—a mountain of a man whose massive frame seemed to dwarf the reinforced chair he occupied, his yellowed eyes staring at some fixed point on the wall behind her with an intensity that made the air in the room feel thick and oppressive.

What struck Unedo most forcefully wasn't his size or the unsettling quality of his silence, but rather the complete absence of anxiety or defensiveness that she'd learned to expect from suspects facing serious charges. Most people, guilty or innocent, displayed some combination of nervous energy, anger, or fear when confronted with the possibility of spending decades in prison. This man radiated a calm that bordered on serenity, broken only by occasional bursts of that disturbing laughter that had so unnerved the arresting officers. Each laugh seemed to emerge from somewhere deep in his chest, a sound devoid of any recognizable human emotion that made Unedo's skin crawl despite her years of experience with violent criminals.

"My name is Detective Martinez," she began, her voice steady and professional despite the unease settling in her stomach. "I've been investigating a series of incidents along the west coast that match the pattern of behavior you're suspected of engaging in here in San Francisco. I'd like to give you an opportunity to tell me your side of the story." She paused, watching for any flicker of reaction in his pale eyes, but his expression remained as fixed and unreadable as a statue carved from granite.

The silence stretched between them like a taut wire, broken only by the distant sounds of the police station beyond the interrogation room door. Unedo had conducted hundreds of interviews over her career, and she understood that silence could be a weapon as potent as any confession when wielded by someone who understood its psychological impact. But there was something different about this man's silence, something that suggested not calculation but rather a complete disconnection from the normal social contracts that governed human interaction.

"The note you left in Jennifer Walsh's car mentioned someone named Uncle Mortimer," Unedo continued, shifting her approach to focus on the personal elements that might penetrate his façade of indifference. "We ran that name through our databases and found some interesting information about a Mortimer Grimwald who died three months ago in Seattle. Substantial estate, family disputes over the inheritance, and a nephew named Roger who contested the will unsuccessfully." She leaned forward slightly, maintaining eye contact even though he continued to stare past her. "Is that you, Roger? Are you Roger Grimwald?"

For the first time since she'd entered the room, something flickered across the suspect's features—not recognition exactly, but perhaps a subtle shift in the quality of his attention. His massive hands, which had been resting motionless on the table, began to flex slowly, thick fingers curling and uncurling in a rhythm that seemed almost hypnotic. The movement was so gradual and controlled that Unedo almost missed it, but her trained eye caught the change and filed it away as potentially significant.

"Uncle Mortimer was a complicated man," she continued, following her instinct that this line of questioning might yield results where direct confrontation had failed. "According to the records we found, he accumulated considerable wealth over his lifetime through real estate investments and business ventures. The kind of wealth that could change someone's life completely, provide security and opportunities that most people only dream about." She paused to let this sink in, watching for any sign that her words were having an impact. "Must have been devastating to lose all of that because of a last-minute change to his will."

The laughter came suddenly and without warning, filling the small room with a sound that seemed to reverberate off the walls and ceiling. It wasn't the bitter laughter of someone reflecting on life's cruel ironies, nor the nervous laughter of someone trying to deflect uncomfortable questions. This was something far more unsettling—a sound that seemed to emerge from a place beyond normal human emotion, carrying with it implications that made Unedo's professional instincts scream warnings she couldn't yet articulate.

"You think this is about money," he said finally, his voice a gravelly whisper that seemed to scrape against the air itself. These were the first coherent words he'd spoken since his arrest, and they carried with them a weight that transformed the entire dynamic of the interrogation. "You think Uncle Mortimer's precious inheritance explains everything, makes it all neat and tidy for your reports and your case files." His yellowed eyes finally focused on her face, and Unedo felt a chill run down her spine at the intelligence she saw there—not the mindless rage of a typical violent criminal, but something far more calculating and deliberate.

"Then help me understand," Unedo replied, fighting to keep her voice steady despite the growing certainty that she was dealing with something beyond her previous experience. "Tell me what this is really about, Roger. Tell me why Jennifer Walsh and the other women became targets of your anger." She spread several photographs across the table between them—crime scene images, victim statements, surveillance footage captures that showed his distinctive silhouette stalking through city streets like some predatory shadow.

Roger's gaze moved slowly across the photographs, and his expression shifted into something that might have been pride if it hadn't been so thoroughly corrupted by malice. "Look at them," he said, his voice gaining strength and conviction. "Look at how they lived their comfortable little lives, walking through the world without fear, without understanding how quickly everything they took for granted could be stripped away." His massive frame seemed to expand as he leaned forward, the chains securing him to the table rattling with the movement. "They needed to learn what I learned when Uncle Mortimer betrayed me. They needed to understand that safety is an illusion, that security can disappear in an instant."

The confession was more chilling for its matter-of-fact delivery than any amount of ranting or emotional outburst could have been. Unedo realized she was listening to someone who had constructed an elaborate philosophical justification for his actions, transforming his personal grievances into a broader mission that elevated stalking and terrorizing innocent women into some twisted form of education or enlightenment. This wasn't a crime of passion or even traditional predatory behavior—this was something far more systematic and ideologically driven.

"And Jennifer Walsh?" Unedo pressed, knowing she needed to establish his involvement in the most serious charge they faced. "What lesson were you trying to teach her?" The question hung in the air between them, and she could see Roger weighing his response, calculating how much to reveal while maintaining whatever psychological advantage he believed he possessed.

"Jennifer was special," he said finally, and something in his tone made Unedo's blood run cold. "She reminded me of someone from a long time ago, someone who made promises she didn't keep. Someone who smiled and laughed and made me believe that the world was a different place than it really is." His hands clenched into fists on the table, and for the first time, Unedo saw genuine emotion crack through his controlled façade. "She needed to learn the truth about disappointment, about betrayal, about what happens when the people you trust decide you're not worth their consideration."

The implications of his words hit Unedo like a physical blow. This wasn't just about his uncle's inheritance or even about the random selection of vulnerable targets. There was a deeper psychological wound driving his actions, something rooted in personal relationships and emotional trauma that had metastasized into a campaign of terror against women who bore some resemblance to figures from his past. The realization made her reassess everything she thought she understood about the case and forced her to confront the possibility that Roger Grimwald's crimes were far more extensive and complex than anyone had initially suspected.**Chapter 2: Echoes of the Past**

Detective Sarah Chen stood outside the interrogation room, watching through the one-way mirror as Unedo Martinez conducted what appeared to be the breakthrough interview they had all been hoping for since Roger Grimwald's arrest. Sarah had been working homicide and major crimes for eight years, but she had never encountered a suspect quite like the massive figure currently dominating the small room beyond the glass. There was something profoundly unsettling about the way he moved, the calculated precision of his gestures and the weight he seemed to give each word, as if every syllable was part of some larger design that only he could fully comprehend. The other detectives who had attempted to question him over the past twenty-four hours had emerged from their sessions frustrated and unnerved, reporting that he seemed to take genuine pleasure in their inability to penetrate his psychological defenses.

What made Grimwald particularly dangerous, in Sarah's professional opinion, was not just his obvious physical advantages or even his apparent lack of remorse for the terror he had inflicted on his victims. Rather, it was the methodical intelligence that seemed to inform every aspect of his behavior, from the sophisticated surveillance techniques he had employed while stalking his targets to the theatrical elements he had introduced into his crimes. This was not a man acting on impulse or driven by uncontrolled urges, but rather someone who had spent considerable time and energy developing a comprehensive approach to psychological warfare that demonstrated both patience and strategic thinking. The note he had left in Jennifer Walsh's abandoned vehicle was not a mistake or a moment of carelessness, but rather a deliberate communication designed to provide law enforcement with exactly the kind of tantalizing clue that would draw them deeper into whatever game he was playing.

The breakthrough moment came when Grimwald began discussing Jennifer Walsh in terms that suggested a much more personal connection than the random stalking behavior that had characterized his other documented crimes. Sarah watched as Unedo leaned forward in response to something he had said, her body language indicating that she had identified a significant development in his narrative. The mention of someone from his past, someone who had made promises she hadn't kept, opened up entirely new avenues of investigation that could potentially lead them to additional victims or provide crucial insight into the psychological factors that had transformed whatever personal grievances he harbored into a systematic campaign of terror against innocent women.

"Detective Chen?" Officer Patricia Reeves appeared at Sarah's shoulder, holding a thick manila folder and wearing the expression of someone who had just discovered information that was going to complicate an already complex investigation. Patricia was one of the department's most thorough researchers, the kind of investigator who could find connections and patterns in databases that other people missed entirely, and her presence at this hour suggested that she had been following up on the leads that had emerged from the interrogation. "I've been running background checks on everything connected to the Mortimer Grimwald estate situation, and I think we might have a much bigger problem than we initially realized."

Sarah reluctantly tore her attention away from the interview room, though she kept one eye on the proceedings beyond the glass as Patricia opened her folder and began spreading documents across the nearby desk. The paperwork appeared to include property records, financial statements, legal documents, and what looked like several newspaper clippings dating back over the past six months. The sheer volume of material suggested that Patricia had been conducting a comprehensive investigation into every aspect of the Grimwald family history, following threads that might provide context for Roger's current behavior and potentially identify additional areas of concern.

"What did you find?" Sarah asked, though something in Patricia's expression made her suspect that she was about to learn information that would significantly complicate their understanding of the case. The arrest of Roger Grimwald had initially seemed like a major breakthrough, the successful conclusion of a multi-state investigation that had been frustrating law enforcement agencies from Seattle to San Francisco. But the more they learned about their suspect and his motivations, the more complex and disturbing the overall picture became, suggesting that his documented crimes might represent only a fraction of his actual criminal activity.

"Mortimer Grimwald died three months ago under circumstances that were officially ruled accidental, but there were enough irregularities in the case to raise questions among the investigating officers," Patricia began, pulling out a police report marked with several highlighting annotations. "He was found dead in his home library, apparently having fallen from a ladder while reaching for books on a high shelf. The fall caused fatal head trauma, and there were no signs of struggle or forced entry into the residence. But the responding officers noted several things that didn't quite fit the accident scenario, including the fact that the books he was allegedly reaching for were titles that he already owned multiple copies of, and the positioning of his body suggested he had fallen backward rather than forward as would be expected from someone losing their balance while climbing."

Sarah felt a cold knot forming in her stomach as the implications of Patricia's research began to crystallize. If Mortimer Grimwald's death had not been accidental, if Roger had been responsible for engineering the circumstances that led to his uncle's fatal fall, then they were dealing with a suspect whose crimes extended far beyond stalking and kidnapping into the realm of premeditated murder. This would also mean that his current campaign of terror against women along the west coast was not his first foray into serious criminal behavior, but rather the continuation of a pattern that had begun with eliminating the family member who had denied him what he considered his rightful inheritance.

"There's more," Patricia continued, pulling out additional documents that appeared to be insurance records and financial statements. "Mortimer Grimwald had changed his will just two weeks before his death, transferring the bulk of his estate from Roger to a distant cousin named Margaret Walsh who lived in San Francisco. The timing of the will change, combined with the suspicious circumstances of his death, would normally have triggered a more thorough investigation, but Roger had an apparently solid alibi for the time period when the accident occurred. He was documented as being in Portland, Oregon, attending a job training seminar, with multiple witnesses and hotel records to confirm his presence there."

The mention of the name Walsh sent a jolt of recognition through Sarah's consciousness, and she immediately understood why Patricia was treating this information as particularly significant. Jennifer Walsh, their current kidnapping victim and the woman whose disappearance had led to Roger's arrest, shared a surname with the cousin who had inherited Mortimer Grimwald's estate. This could not possibly be a coincidence, which meant that Roger's selection of Jennifer as a target was not the result of random stalking behavior but rather part of a calculated revenge plot against the family members who had benefited from his uncle's decision to disinherit him.

"Please tell me that Margaret Walsh and Jennifer Walsh are not related," Sarah said, though she already knew from Patricia's expression that her hopes were about to be disappointed. The case was evolving from a serial stalking investigation into something far more complex and dangerous, a family revenge plot that had already claimed at least one life and was threatening to claim more. If Roger had spent the past three months systematically targeting members of the Walsh family, then Jennifer's disappearance was not an escalation of his stalking behavior but rather the next phase of a carefully orchestrated campaign of vengeance.

"Margaret Walsh is Jennifer's aunt," Patricia confirmed, pulling out a family tree diagram that she had apparently constructed to track the relationships between all the relevant parties. "But here's where it gets really disturbing—Margaret Walsh died six weeks ago in what was initially classified as a suicide. She was found in her apartment bathroom, having apparently overdosed on prescription medications, with a note expressing remorse over family conflicts and financial pressures. The investigating officers found no evidence of foul play, and her death was processed as a straightforward suicide case. But given what we now know about Roger Grimwald's presence in the San Francisco area and his apparent vendetta against the Walsh family, I think we need to seriously reconsider the circumstances of her death."

Sarah stared at the documents spread across the desk, her mind racing through the implications of this new information and the way it transformed their understanding of everything that had happened over the past several months. If Roger Grimwald had successfully murdered both his uncle and the cousin who had inherited the estate, then his stalking of other women along the west coast had served as an elaborate cover story, a pattern of seemingly random criminal behavior designed to obscure his true motives and deflect attention from the systematic elimination of his family members. The sophistication of such a plan suggested a level of criminal intelligence and long-term planning that made him far more dangerous than they had initially realized.

"We need to get this information to Detective Martinez immediately," Sarah said, watching as Unedo continued her interview with Grimwald, apparently unaware that she was sitting across from someone who was potentially responsible for at least two murders in addition to his documented stalking crimes. "If Jennifer Walsh is still alive, and if Roger's ultimate goal is to eliminate everyone who benefited from his uncle's will, then we might be dealing with a time-sensitive hostage situation rather than a standard kidnapping case. He might be keeping her alive as part of some twisted plan to make her suffer for her family's perceived betrayal before ultimately killing her."

The realization that they might be running out of time to save Jennifer Walsh added a new urgency to the investigation, but it also raised troubling questions about Roger's willingness to confess to his stalking activities while remaining silent about the more serious charges he potentially faced. His apparent cooperation with the interrogation process might be nothing more than another layer of psychological manipulation, a way to control the flow of information while drawing law enforcement deeper into whatever final phase of his revenge plot he was attempting to implement. The theatrical elements of his behavior, from the dramatic note left in Jennifer's car to his disturbing laughter during questioning, suggested someone who was taking perverse pleasure in the cat-and-mouse game he was playing with the authorities.

Patricia gathered up her documents and prepared to interrupt the ongoing interview, but before she could move toward the interrogation room door, they both heard Roger Grimwald's voice rising in volume and intensity as he continued his conversation with Detective Martinez. His words were muffled by the soundproofing, but the emotional weight behind them was unmistakable, suggesting that Unedo had succeeded in penetrating his psychological defenses and was now extracting information that could be crucial to locating Jennifer Walsh and understanding the full scope of his criminal activities. The breakthrough they had all been hoping for might finally be within reach, but Sarah couldn't shake the feeling that whatever Roger was about to reveal would only deepen the darkness surrounding this case.**Chapter 3: The Web Unravels**

Detective Unedo Martinez felt the temperature in the interrogation room seem to drop several degrees as Roger Grimwald's demeanor underwent a subtle but unmistakable transformation, his earlier calculated composure giving way to something far more volatile and unpredictable. The massive man's yellowed eyes had taken on a gleam that reminded her uncomfortably of a predator that had been toying with its prey and was now preparing to deliver the killing blow. His hands, which had been resting relatively still on the metal table, began to drum against the surface in a complex rhythm that seemed to match some internal cadence only he could hear, and the sound filled the small room with an ominous percussive beat that made Unedo's nerves feel stretched to their breaking point. What she had initially interpreted as the random stalking behavior of a man whose grief and rage had been channeled into violence against vulnerable women was actually something far more systematic and calculating, a carefully orchestrated campaign designed to inflict maximum psychological damage on specific targets while creating enough background noise to obscure his true motivations from law enforcement. The realization that she had been investigating not a serial stalker but rather someone engaged in a complex family vendetta made her reassess every piece of evidence they had collected and every assumption they had made about his psychological profile and likely future behavior.

"You want to know about Jennifer Walsh," Roger said, his voice carrying a note of satisfaction that made Unedo's skin crawl with its implications. "You want to understand why she was special, why she deserved more attention than the others who were just practice, just preparation for the real work I came here to accomplish." He leaned back in his chair as much as his restraints would allow, and for the first time since she had entered the room, Unedo saw him smile in a way that revealed the depth of malice that had been simmering beneath his carefully controlled exterior. "She changed her route to work every day, varied her schedule, even installed new locks on her apartment and upgraded her building's security system. But she didn't understand that I had been watching her for weeks before she ever became aware of my presence, learning everything about her life and her habits and her relationships. By the time she started taking precautions, I already knew more about her daily existence than most people know about their closest family members."

The methodical nature of his surveillance activities painted a picture of someone who approached stalking with the same systematic precision that a legitimate investigator might bring to a complex case, and Unedo realized that Roger's months of practice on other victims had allowed him to refine his techniques to a level of sophistication that would have been extremely difficult for even a security-conscious target to detect or counter. The thought that Jennifer Walsh had been living under this kind of intensive surveillance for weeks without realizing the full extent of her danger made Unedo feel a deep sense of professional failure, as if the law enforcement community had somehow let down this woman who had tried so hard to protect herself from a threat that was far more organized and persistent than anyone could have reasonably anticipated.

"Where is she now, Roger?" Unedo asked, forcing herself to maintain eye contact despite the revulsion she felt at his obvious pleasure in recounting his crimes. "What did you do with Jennifer Walsh after you took her from Golden Gate Park?" The question hung in the air between them like a challenge, and she could see him weighing his response, calculating how much information to reveal while maintaining whatever psychological advantage he believed his knowledge gave him over the investigation. His earlier willingness to discuss his stalking activities had been encouraging, but she suspected that he would be far more reluctant to provide details about Jennifer's current location or condition, especially if his ultimate plan involved harming her in ways that would constitute capital murder charges.

The sound of the interrogation room door opening interrupted the tense moment, and Unedo turned to see Detective Sarah Chen entering with a folder full of documents and an expression that suggested she was bringing information that would significantly complicate an already complex situation. The interruption clearly annoyed Roger, who had been building toward some kind of revelation that might have provided crucial insight into Jennifer's whereabouts or condition, but Sarah's presence also indicated that developments outside the interrogation room had reached a point where they could not wait for the completion of his confession. She placed the folder on the table between them and began extracting documents that appeared to include police reports, financial records, and what looked like family genealogy charts. The official nature of the paperwork suggested that Sarah had been conducting a comprehensive background investigation into every aspect of Roger's family history and the circumstances surrounding his uncle's death, following threads that might provide context for his current criminal behavior and potentially reveal additional victims or areas of concern.

Roger's reaction to the appearance of the documents was immediate and dramatic, his controlled demeanor evaporating in favor of something that looked suspiciously like panic mixed with rage. His massive frame tensed against his restraints, and the chains securing him to the table began to rattle as he struggled against the limitations of his confinement. The transformation was so sudden and complete that Unedo instinctively reached for the emergency alert button that would summon additional security personnel to the interrogation room, but before she could activate it, Roger's struggles ceased as abruptly as they had begun, leaving him staring at the documents with an intensity that made the air in the room feel charged with potential violence.

"You don't understand what you're dealing with," Roger said, his voice now carrying a note of something that might have been desperation if it hadn't been so thoroughly corrupted by malice and calculation. "Uncle Mortimer and that bitch Margaret thought they could just erase me from the family history, pretend that thirty years of promises and commitments meant nothing because some legal document said so. They thought they could take everything that should have been mine and give it to someone who never even knew the old man existed, someone who had no appreciation for what those resources represented or what I had sacrificed to earn them." Something that made him laugh in the darkness of his makeshift lair, a sound that would have chilled anyone who heard it.

The woman in the red coat turned down a side street, and Roger's lips pulled back in what might have been a smile if it hadn't been so devoid of warmth. He pushed away from the wall, his heavy footsteps silent despite his size. Years of hunting in the woods with Uncle Mortimer had taught him how to move without sound, how to track prey without being detected. Those skills served a different purpose now.

Twenty-three hundred miles away in Anchorage, Lady Unedo Martinez was reviewing crime scene photographs by the pale light of her desk lamp. The police station was nearly empty at this hour, just the night shift officers and a few detectives burning the midnight oil on active cases. Unedo had earned her reputation as one of Alaska's most tenacious investigators through cases exactly like this one—the kind that kept her awake at night and haunted her dreams.

The photos spread across her desk told a disturbing story. Three women in three different cities, all found in similar circumstances. No physical violence, no signs of struggle, but each victim reported being stalked for weeks before they disappeared entirely from their routines, only to resurface days later with no memory of where they'd been. The psychological trauma was severe and lasting.

"Working late again, Martinez?" Detective Jim Kowalski dropped into the chair across from her desk, a steaming cup of coffee in his hands. Jim was a good cop, methodical and thorough, but he lacked the intuitive leap that made Unedo exceptional at her job. "You know, normal people go home after their shift ends."

Her dark hair fell across her face as she leaned forward, studying the details that everyone else seemed to miss. "Look at this pattern, Jim. Seattle, Portland, now reports coming in from San Francisco. He's moving south along the coast, and the frequency is increasing."
